content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A group of students is asked to take measurements to create a graph that can be used to determine the mass <math alttext="m sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> of a block. The students have a set of springs that are attached at one end to the ceiling. Each spring has a different, known spring constant and a loop to which the block can be attached. The students are also given a meterstick but do not have a scale or a balance. (a) Describe a procedure for collecting data that can be graphed to determine <math alttext="m sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>. Include steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

frqParts.text: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A group of students is asked to take measurements to create a graph that can be used to determine the mass <math alttext="m sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> of a block. The students have a set of springs that are attached at one end to the ceiling. Each spring has a different, known spring constant and a loop to which the block can be attached. The students are also given a meterstick but do not have a scale or a balance. (a) Describe a procedure for collecting data that can be graphed to determine <math alttext="m sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>. Include steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) Describe how the data collected in part (a) could be graphed, and how that graph would be analyzed to determine <math alttext="m sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>.

Another group of students is given an identical set of springs with known spring constants which can be attached to a wall. The springs can also be attached at the other end to a block of known mass <math alttext="m sub 0 equals 2 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mstyle></math>. The students attach the block to one of the springs as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> and pull the block to the right. The students record the maximum stretch of the spring before the force of friction is no longer able to keep the block at rest when the box is released. The students replace the spring and repeat the experiment. The following table shows the data collected by the students.Spring Constant <math alttext="in newtons per meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo mathvariant="bold" stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="bold">N</mi><mo mathvariant="bold">/</mo><mi mathvariant="bold">m</mi><mo mathvariant="bold" stretchy="false">)</mo></math>Max Stretch from Equilibrium <math alttext="in meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo mathvariant="bold" stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="bold">m</mi><mo mathvariant="bold" stretchy="false">)</mo></math><math alttext="8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>8</mn></math><math alttext="0.74" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.74</mn></math><math alttext="10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn></math><math alttext="0.55" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.55</mn></math><math alttext="12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>12</mn></math><math alttext="0.50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.50</mn></math><math alttext="15" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>15</mn></math><math alttext="0.42" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.42</mn></math><math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math><math alttext="0.27" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.27</mn></math>The students correctly determine that the relationship between spring constant of the spring and the maximum stretch of the spring <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>, is given by <math alttext="x equals the fraction with numerator mu sub s, end sub, times m sub 0, end sub, times g, and denominator k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>s</mi></msub><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mi>g</mi></mrow><mi>k</mi></mfrac></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="mu sub s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></mstyle></math> is the coefficient of static friction between the block and the surface. The students create a graph with <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> plotted on the vertical axis.(c)i. Indicate which measured or calculated quantity could be plotted on the horizontal axis to yield a linear graph whose slope can be used to calculate an experimental value coefficient of static friction <math alttext="mu sub s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></mstyle></math> between the block and the surface. You may use the remaining columns in the table, as needed, to record any quantities (including units) that are not already in the table.Vertical:_____<math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>_____ Horizontal:__________

ii. On the grid shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i) that can be used to determine <math alttext="mu sub s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></mstyle></math>. Scale the graph as appropriate. Clearly label the horizontal axis, including units.
iii. Draw a best–fit line for the data graphed in part (c)(ii).

(d) Calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="mu sub s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></mstyle></math> using the best-fit line you drew in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> in part (c)(iii).

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
